div.l: Lo here oure siluer redy forto spende
This Miller in to toun his doughter sende
For ale and breed / and roosted hem a goos
And bonde hire hors / it sholde namore go loos
And in his owen Chambre / hem made a bedde
With sheetes and chalons faire y spredde
Nat from his owen bedde / ten foot other twelue
His doughter hadde a bedde al by hire selue
Ryght in the same chambre by and by
It myght be no bette and cause why
Ther was no roumer herborw in the place
TheyTheThey soupen and they speken hem to solace
And drynken eủer stronge ale at the beste
Aboute mydnyght / went they to reste
Wele hath this Millere vernysshed his heed
Full Pale he was for dronken / and noght reed
He yexeth / and he speketh thurgh the nose
As he were on the quakke / or on the pose
To bedde he goth / and with hym gooth his wyfe
As any Iay / he light was and Iolyfe
So was hire Ioly whistle wele I wette
The cradel at hire beddes feet was sette
To rokken and to yeue the childe to souke
And whan that drunken / al was in the crowke
To bedde wente the doughter right a noon
To bedde goth Aleyn / and also Iohn
Ther nas namore hem hem hem hemhem nedid no dwale
This Millere hath so wisly bybbed ale
That as an hors he fnorteth in his sleepe
Ne of his taille ende he toke no kepe
His wyfe bare hym a bordoıı̄un a full stronge
Men myght hire rowtyng herēn a furlonge
The wenche routeth eeke / ꝑpar compaignye
Aleyn the Clerke / that herde thys melodye
He pouketh Iohn / and seyde slepystowe 
Herde thow eủer suche a songe er nowe
Lo slyke a coupelyng / is y mel hem alle
A wilde fuyr on hire bodies falle
Who herkened eủer slyke a ferly thyng
Ye they shal haue the floure of il endyng
